title: Engineering Startups
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken SEEM3450
description: Overall ecosystem in engineering startups, including ideation, realization and growth stages. Ideation: Factors that drive continuous creative product innovation. Realization: Introduce the concept of business model and use business canvas for development of a model. Growth: Introduce the concept of business plan especially focus on fund raising.

title: Operations Research I
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: Review of linear algebra. Linear programming: simplex methods, duality and sensitivity analysis. Network flows: transportation and assignment problems, shortest paths, minimum spanning trees, network simplex method and multicommodity flows. Modelling issues in linear programming and network flows applications.
outcome: Having fundamental knowledge of the art of modeling with linear programming  • Skilled at solving linear programming problems by mathematical methods  • Able to solve some network flow problems by mathematical methods  • Able to solve linear programming problems and some network flow problems by computers  • To see the Programme Learning Outcomes, please refer to http://www.se.cuhk.edu.hk/programmes/pl_outcome.html

title: Engineering Economics
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken SEEM2510 or ESTR2500.
description: Principles of engineering economy. Value and cost; cash flows. Economic analysis of alternatives, technological, social and human factors. Models involving allocation and scheduling of resources. Analytical techniques for evaluating industrial projects. Relationship between economics of technical choice and industrial productivity. Basic financial accounting concepts; accounting cycle; financial statements.
outcome: After completing the course you should be able to:  - understand basic cost concepts, terminology, and methods to estimate and optimize cost of design projects.  - understand time value of money and apply this knowledge through various methods to evaluate alternative projects.  - learn the techniques to account for depreciation, tax, and inflation in the evaluation of engineering projects.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: 1. Engineering Economic Analysis, by Donald G. Newnan, Ted G. Eschenbach, and Jerome P. Lavelle, Oxford University Press. 2. Engineering Economy, by William G. Sullivan, Elin M. Wicks, and C. Patrick Koelling, 15th edition, Pearson Education Limited 2012.

title: Introduction to Data Science
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR2540.
description: This course presents an introductory roadmap into the newly emerged and rapidly evolving field of data science, with the objective of introducing the problem-solving mindset in a data-intensive context.The course projects data science as a productive synthesis of its parent disciplines, including mathematics, statistics, computing, data mining, system science and data visualization, etc. Such a productive synthesis is applicable across many fields to bring about scientific discovery through data-intensive, analytical methods. This course aims to help navigate students in taking more advanced courses in its parent disciplines to build up their expertise in data science. We cover topics including:History and impact of Data Science.Collecting Data: sources, types and categorization of data.Visualising Data: summary statistics, data display, data dictionaries, schema and graphical visualization.Analysing Data: pattern recognition, correlations and relationships, hypotheses testing, statistical significance.Investigating Data: data mining, machine learning, inference, meta-data, modeling, eliciting meaning and validation.Applicational contexts: Examples of useful applications from case studies.
outcome: 1. Knowledge of fundamental scientific principles that underpin data science. 2. Development of basic skills in collecting, visualizing, analysing and investigating data. 3. Awareness of how data science and big data can be applied in many companies and industries and in daily life.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: The elements of statistical learning : data mining, inference, and prediction / Trevor Hastie, Robert Tibshirani, Jerome Friedman (2nd edition) New York : Springer, 2009.

title: Fundamentals in Financial Engineering
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: Overview of financial markets for securities, foreign exchange, options and futures; special emphasis on understanding of the market characteristics; interpretation of financial statements of an organization in terms of liquidity, solvency, profitability, efficiency and growth.
outcome: 1. Able to appreciate the role that financial markets and institutions play in the society  2. Able to apply knowledge and techniques of mathematics and engineering to solve some elementary financial problems  3. Understanding the professional and ethical responsibility facing a financial manager and able to know how to enhance them 4. Able to stay abreast of contemporary financial issues and skilled at using the learned principles to analyze them

title: Systems Engineering Practicum
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG2602.
description: Industrial and professional workshops or seminars related to Systems Engineering practicum.
outcome: At its completion, the students should understand the field of Systems Engineering & Engineering Management, how to plan for and develop their career, and how to make ethical decisions.
syllabus: Industrial and professional workshops or seminars
required_readings: Reference materials will be provided in the lecture notes and reserved in the University’s library. URLs to videos showed in the lectures are also included in the lecture notes.

title: System Simulation
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Prerequisites: SEEM2430 or ENGG2430 or ENGG2450 or ESTR2002 or ESTR2005 or with the approval of the course instructor.
description: System concept and mathematical models. Model building: parameter estimation and data analysis. Elementary queuing theory and applications: M/M/S models. Introduction to simulation and simulation language. Principles of discrete event simulation. Random number generators and output analysis. Optimization via simulation. Applications to production and manufacturing systems.
outcome: 1. Able to obtain the general theory, methodology and technical skills of all the important aspects of a simulation study, including input analysis, modeling, random number generating, modeling validation, output data analysis, and simulation programming  2. Able to describe the behavior of systems  3. Able to construct theories or hypothesis that account for the observed behavior  4. Able to use the model to predict future behavior, i.e., the effects produced by changes in the system or in its method of operation.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.

title: Information Systems Analysis and Design
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Prerequisite: SEEM3460 or ESTR3504 or with the approval of the course instructor.
description: Information system development life cycle; user requirement analysis; feasibility study; cost/benefit analysis; systems analysis tools such as data flow diagrams and process specification tools. Real time systems analysis. Transformation from analysis to design. Structured chart. System design quality heuristics such as coupling and cohesion. System design packaging and design optimization: CASE (Computer-Aided Software Engineering) Tools.
outcome: 1. Understand System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) and its different forms in practice.  2. Able to perform data analysis and design using Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD) 3. Able to perform functional analysis and design using Data Flow Diagram (DFD)
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.

title: Operations Research II
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3500.
description: Non-linear programming: convex sets and functions; local and global optima; Lagrange multipliers; optimality conditions for unconstrained problems; descent methods; constrained optimization; Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions; solution methods. Non-differentiable optimization: integer programming models; formulations; cutting-plane methods; branch-and-bound. Dynamic programming: models and formulation; Bellman's equations; solution methods.
outcome: 1. Ability to make logical statements using 0/1 variables.  2. Ability to solve, using standard software, simple non-linear and integer programs. 3. Have an understanding of optimality for non-linear programs. 4. Ability to formulate simple stochastic and deterministic dynamic programs.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: 1. F.S. Hillier and G.J. Lieberman, Introduction to Operations Research, 9th Edition, McGraw-Hill, 2010. 2. H.A. Taha, Operations Research: An Introduction, 8th Edition, Prentice Hall, 2007 or 3. H.A. Taha, Operations Research: An Introduction, 9th Edition, Prentice Hall, 2011 4. D.G. Luenberger and Y.Y. Ye, Linear and Nonlinear Programming, 3rd Edition, Springer, 2008.

title: Engineering Innovation and Entrepreneurship
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3502.
description: Factors that drive continuous creative product innovation. Study of processes of creating, assessing and pursuing product opportunities. Evaluation of new product ideas and risk assessment of commercialization. Product development strategies in industrial marketing. Understanding the behaviour of buyer. Formulation and implementation of innovative marketing strategy and business plan.
outcome: 1. Understand the influences of technological, environmental, social and cultural considerations on design decsions and new product/service development;  2. Competent to generate new product/service ideas, and to critique business viability of such ideas;  3. Able to develop a proposal for a new venture;  4. Able to analyze and debate the basic issues, the risks, challenges and rewards related to innovation and new ventures.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: 1. Timmons, Jeffry A. and S. Spenelli, New venture creation: Entrepreneurship for the 21st century (7th Edition), 2007, Irwin/McGraw-Hill. 2. Cornwall, J.R., D.O. Vang and J.M. Hartman, Entrepreneurial Financial Management: An Applied Approach, 2004, Prentice-Hall. 3. Worthington, I. and C. Britton, The Business Environment (5th Edition), 2006, FT Prentice-Hall.

title: Computer Processing Systems Concepts
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3504. Prerequisite: CSCI1110 or CSCI1510 or ENGG1110 or ESTR1002 or with the approval of the course instructor.
description: Principles of operating system functions. Introduction to linkers, loaders, memory management and process management. Performance analysis of scheduling algorithm. Applications based on systems such as UNIX, Cloud computing concepts and their evaluation and selection based on application needs.
outcome: 1. Able to understand how computer works 2. Able to understand the basic principle of operating systems  3. Able to design and develop software to solve problems
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: Operating Systems Internals and Design Principles, William Stallings, Prentice Hall.

title: Information Systems Management
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: In-depth discussion of the challenges, techniques and technologies associated with the management of IT in a competitive environment. The linkage of IT to business strategy and business process re-engineering. Type of information systems: MIS, DSS, TPS. Development process. Information system planning. Systems project management and control. IT acquisition, budgeting and deployment. Performance evaluation and auditing. Operations management. Privacy and security.
outcome: 1. Understand basic concepts of information systems  2. Appreciate strategic values of information systems in an enterprise  3. Understand the use of enterprise systems  4. Understand the applications of management support systems  5. Examine the impact of the Internet and E-business  6. Understand software development process  7. Appreciate the use of outsourcing  8. Understand the process of managing information systems functions  9. Appreciate the value of decision support in various business functions
required_readings: As recommended by course teacher.
recommended_readings: As recommended by course teacher.

title: Quality Control and Management
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Prerequisites: SEEM2430 or ENGG2430 or ENGG2450 or ESTR2002 or ESTR2005 or with the approval of the course instructor.
description: Quality planning, control and improvement. Sampling theory. Statistical quality control theory applied to production operations. Specification and control charts for monitoring production systems. Quality engineering - the Taguchi Method. Quality control issues of manufacturing and service industry. Case studies of quality control problems in industry. Use of computer aids. Introduction to ISO 9000.
outcome: 1. Understood the basic concepts of quality and quality management.  2. Able to develop control charts according to types of data, including attribute data and variable data. 3. Able to diagnose and analyze out-of-control patterns in a control chart.  4. Able to evaluate process capability and improve a process using the concept of process capability.  5. Able to design experiments to reveal the relationships between dependent variables and independent variables. 6. Understood the requirements and certification process of ISO 9000.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.

title: Human-computer Interaction
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken AIST3510
description: This course provides an introduction to the fast evolving field of human computer interaction (HCI). HCI is a multidisciplinary subject concerning the design, implemen-tation and evaluation of interactive computing systems for human use, and the study of major phenomena surrounding them. We will provide a broad overview of the field, including the theory and principles underlying good designs, with an emphasis on the interface design process, development and evaluation. We will also sample some state-of-the-art technologies in HCI, such as speech recognition, haptics, virtual reality, software agents and computer supported cooperative work.

title: Engineering and Technology Management
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: Managerial functions: planning, organizing, influencing and control. Strategic formulation and decision making. Strategic and operational considerations of technology. Management of research, engineering design and production functions. Project screening and selection. Project structuring, scheduling and budgeting. Project control.

title: Fundamentals in Information Systems
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3506.
description: Basic elements of information systems, their concepts and interrelations. Database systems: database models, relational database, database application programming. Information retrieval: models, indexing, performance evaluation. Expert systems: knowledge and data engineering, expert system shell, application studies.
outcome: At the completion of the course, students are expected to gain knowledge on how to design a semantics model using E-R model to capture applications semantics, to design a relational database which can handle data inconsistencies, to understand how to issue complex queries to access that, and how efficient to process such queries. The course project will assist students to understand how to support a real application using database technologies.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: Database System Concepts (sixth edition), by Avi Silberschatz, Henry F. Korth, and S. Sudarshan, McGraw-Hill, 2010.

title: Stochastic Models
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3508. Pre-requisite: SEEM2430 or ENGG2430 ENGG2450 or ESTR2002 or ESTR2005 or with the approval of the course instructor.
description: Review of basic probability. Probabilistic dynamic programming. Stochastic processes and Markov chains. Birth-and-death processes and queuing models. Stochastic inventory models: single and multiple periods. Forecasting and time series. Markov decision processes.
outcome: At the conclusion of this course, students are expected to  - understand the strength and limitations of various econometric models, - be able to analyze them using statistical tools, - understand the basics of the theory of stochastic processes and use the theory to analyze some simple systems.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: 1. Richard A. Johnson, Probability and Statistics for Engineers (8th Edition), Pearson Education, Inc., 2010 2. Frederick S. Hillier, Gerald J. Lieberman, Introduction to Operations Research (9th Edition), McGraw-Hill, Inc., 2010. 3. Robert S. Pindyck, Daniel L. Rubinfeld, Econometric Models and Economic Forecasts (4th Edition), McGraw-Hill, Inc., 1997. 4. Sheldon M. Ross, Introduction to Probability Modeles (10th Edition), Academic Press, 2009.

title: Risk Analysis for Financial Engineering
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: Analysis and modelling of market, credit, and operational risks in Financial Engineering. Fundamental financial instruments and derivatives: forward, futures, options, and swaps. Sources and models of market risks: interest rate, foreign exchange rate, equity prices, and commodity prices. Major credit scoring and rating models: Z-score, Logit, and Merton. Major commercial applications and systems, KMV and CreditMetrics. Different approaches to measure Value at Risk (VaR): historical, parametric, and Monte Carlo.
outcome: After completing the course you should be able to:  - understand the fundamental techniques in measuring the interest rate risk of a financial institution.  - understand the concept lying behind the VaR and the techniques to evaluate it. - understand the fundamental techniques in measuring the credit risk of an individual loan and a portfolio of loans. - understand the fundamental techniques in measuring the liquidity risk of a depository institution. - understand different ways to hedge the risks of a financial institution.

title: Investment Science
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3509.
description: Basic theory of interests, fixed income securities, the term structure of interest rates, valuation of a firm, decision making under uncertainty, mean-variance portfolio theory, capital asset pricing model, models and data, basics of forward and futures contracts, basic options theory.
outcome: 1. Understand the fundamental principles of investment science, especially the no-arbitrage argument;  2. Understand the market structure and able to perform analysis, including fixed-income securities and term structure of interest rates; 3. Able to use data to construct mathematical models for portfolio selection, able to solve some basic portfolio optimization problems, and able to derive financial implication to guide real practice; 4. Able to understand the concept of market equilibrium and some basic pricing models as well as their investment implications; 5. Able to understand the risk aversion principle and general principles for guiding portfolio selection; 6. Skilled in computer programming (EXCEL) to implement solutions to investment decision.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.

title: Introduction to Logistics and Supply Chain Management
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3514 or ESTR4500 or ESTR4502 or SEEM4600 or SEEM4610.
description: Logistics and Supply Chain Management involves various flows (e.g., materials flow and information flow) among all of the entities that contribute value to a product, from the source of raw materials to end customers. This course will focus on the basic concepts, models and techniques for effective strategic management of an integrated and coordinated supply chain. The emphasis is on recognizingkey tradeoffs, analyzing system characteristics, and understanding effectiveness of tactics such as risk pooling, inventory policies, collaboration, and information sharing.

title: Service Management
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3510.
description: Overview of the operations functions of service organizations. Examination of methods for designing and operating service delivery systems in the health care, financial, hospitality, telecommunication, and logistics industry. Discussion on service strategy, services for individual and corporate customers, service technologies, process and facility design, management of waiting lines, demand forecasting, demand and supply management, service quality, staffing and scheduling.
outcome: 1. Able to analyze a service organization in a structural way (such as the nature of its service(s), the challenges and major tradeoffs pertinent to its nature, etc.).  2. Competent to identify new service product opportunities  3. Able to analyze the effectiveness of an existing system by applying analytical skills that students have learnt in earlier courses  4. Able to identify options and then analyze them in decision making of service operation.  5. Able to formulate a problem setting into a mathematical model, know how to solve it and understand the underlying assumptions and therefore its limitations and applicability.  6. Understanding of major issues in service operations management and grasp of major concepts in revenue management.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: 1. Jay Heizer and Barry Render, Operations Management, 11th Edition, Pearson, 2014. 2. Judith Hurwitz et al., Services Management, Wiley Publishing Inc. 2009.

title: Fundamentals in Decision and Data Analytics
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements:
1. Pre-requisites:
(a) ENGG1110/ESTR1002, ENGG1120/ESTR1005, ENGG1130/ESTR1006, ENGG2440/ESTR2004, ENGG2760/ESTR2018, ENGG2780/ESTR2020 & MATH1510; or (b) with course instructor's approval.
2. Not for students who have taken ESTR3516 or SEEM4480.
description: This course introduces the basic concepts of decision and data analytics from a statistical and probability view. Topics include linear regression, classification, sampling techniques, model selection, decision trees, principal component analysis, clustering, and their applications in decision making.

title: Technology, Consulting and Analytics in Practice
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3512, ESTR4504 or SEEM4680.
description: This course presents students with a broad overview of the latest technologies, e.g. cloud computing, social media, mobile applications, etc. that are impacting the business world everyday. Students are presented with case studies to illustrate how advanced technologies are used in solutions to real-world problems. Students will be presented with opportunities to adopt design thinking techniques to come up with innovative ideas for problem-solving, and optionally create pilot implementations of their design. The SEEM department will invite participation by industry leaders and practitioners to share their insights in this course.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students would be able to: - Acquire an appreciation of how advanced technologies are impacting the business world everyday; - Understand the cycle of problem discovery, motivating the design of innovation solutions; - Gain practical experience in the design thinking process to nurture innovations; - Acquire skills in project planning, group communication, discussion facilitation, team work and logical thinking skills through active class participation, article writing, collaborative problem solving and project presentation.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: 1. Wells, S. (2009) Choosing the future: The power of strategic thinking, Boston: Butterworth-Heinemann 2. Greiner, L. & Poulflet, F. (Eds.) (2009) Management Consulting Today and Tomorrow, New York: Routledge 3. Biggs, D.M. (2010) Management Consulting: A guide for students, London: Cengage Learning 4. Kipping, M. & Clark T. (2012) The Oxford handbook of management consulting, London: Oxford University Press 5. Parthasarthy, S (2007) Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP)-A managerial and technical perspective, New Delhi: New Age International 6. Cameron, E. & Green. M. (2012) Making sense of change management, London: Kogan Page Limited 7. Fader, P. (2011) Customer Centricity, Philadelphia: Wharton Digital Press 8. Burkholder, N.C. (2006) Outsourcing-The definitive view, applications and implications, New Jersey: John Wiley & Sons, Inc. 9. Reiss, G. (2007) Project Management Demystified, Oxon: Taylor & Francis

title: Decision Methodology and Applications
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements:
1. Prerequisites: 
(a) SEEM2430 or ENGG2430 or ENGG2450 or ESTR2002 or ESTR2005; and 
(b) SEEM3440 or ESTR3500
or with the approval of the course instructor.
2. Not for students who have taken ESTR3516 or SEEM3650.
description: Review of basic decision analysis concepts and methodologies. Single- and multiattribute utility theory under both certainty and uncertainty. Assessment methodologies; strength of preference; risk attitude; trade-off judgements. Prior information; subjective probability; Bayesian analysis; sequential analysis. Multiobjective optimization; methods for generating Pareto optimum solutions; methods with prior assessment of preferences; method with progressive assessment of preferences. Risk sharing and group decisions. Cooperative and non-cooperative game methods. Applications to risk analysis and management.
outcome: 1. Able to describe and identify the essential characteristics of decision-making problems  2. Able to access the subjective judgment about uncertainty and quantify subjective preference of consequences 3. Able to quantify the value of information and make better decision with more information 4. Able to apply quantitative methods to draw inferences and solve decision problems
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.

title: Open Systems for E-Commerce
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Prerequisite: SEEM3460 or ESTR3504 or with the approval of the course instructor.
description: Overview the technologies and mechanisms of open systems. Advanced Internet applications including electronic commerce using open system and Web technologies. Multimedia applications over open systems. Applications on wireless and mobile network.
outcome: 1. Able to apply the knowledge on networking in terms of algorithms, protocol design, large system design  2. Able to design/implement e-commerce, distributed web applications on the Internet  3. Able to conduct experimental studies and analyze networking related performance  4. Able to formulate and solve engineering problems 5. Able to understand the impact of engineering solutions in a wide context for supporting new web-services, web applications, and e-commerce applications.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.

title: System Design and Implementation
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: System implementation methodology construction, testing and maintenance. Software re-engineering and reverse engineering; software reliability and programme quality assurance; software reusability Software metrics. Performance engineering. Configuration management. Object-oriented system design. Use of computer-aided tools.

title: Logistics Management
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3514 or ESTR4500 or ESTR4510 or SEEM3620 or SEEM4750.
description: The integrated logistics management concept. Customer service. Channels of distribution. Transportation; vehicle routing and scheduling; freight consolidation. Facility location and network planning. Storage and material handling systems. Information systems for order processing and inventory tracking. Purchasing and supply scheduling. Business process re-engineering.Third-party logistics. Global logistics.
outcome: 1. Understanding of the characteristics of logistics industry in Hong Kong.  2. Familiar with the major decision issues in air, sea and land transport.  3. Able to assess a shipment/logistics/distribution solution.  4. Able to formulate a practical problem setting into a mathematical model, know how to solve it and understand the underlying assumptions and therefore its limitations and applicability.  5. Understanding of commonly used methods for practical problems.  6. Competent to associate industrial initiatives/new practices with basic concepts in logistics management.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: Ghiani, G., G. Laporte and R. Musmanno, Introduction to Logistics Systems Management, 2013, Wiley.
recommended_readings: 1. Goetschalckx, M., Supply Chain Engineering, 2011, Springer. 2. Christopher, M., Logistics and Supply Chain Management (4th edition), 2011, Financial Times/Prentice-Hall. 3. Ballou, R.H., Business Logistics Management/Supply Chain Management, 5th edition, 2004, Prentice-Hall. 4. Powell and Baker, Management Science: the art of modeling with spreadsheets (2nd Edition), 2009, Wiley.

title: Supply Chain Management
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3514 or ESTR4502 or ESTR4510 or SEEM3620 or SEEM4750.
description: Management of moving raw materials, in-process inventory and finished-goods; transferring information and payment. Topics include: distribution; inventory management; purchasing and supplier management; the value of information and information technology; supply chain integration and strategic partnering; product design for supply chain management.
outcome: 1. Able to generate new ideas and apply relevant techniques to improve the performance of a supply chain.  2. Able to identify engineering problems degrading the supply chain efficiency and propose solutions for better management of inventory, demand, transportation, and distribution.  3. Able to design and optimize a supply chain appropriate for a particular product while achieving specified service/production targets and meeting realistic constraints.  4. Competent in communicating effectively the proposed solutions to different parties in the supply chain. 5. Skilled at utilizing IT tools to analyze and implement solution methods, for example spreadsheet tools for implementing demand forecasting methods. 6. Able to introduce new concepts to management of a supply chain due to contemporary issues such as globalization; for example, outsourcing, coordination etc.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
recommended_readings: 1. Nahmias, Production and Operations Analysis (6th Edition), 2008, Irwin/McGraw-Hill. 2. Cachon and Terwiesch. Matching Supply with Demand: An Introduction to Operations Management, 3rd Edition, 2012, McGraw-Hill.

title: E-Commerce Data Mining
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: This course introduces data mining techniques suitable for E-Commerce applications. It covers the following topics: prediction, association rule mining, rule induction, trend and deviation analysis, pattern visualization and data mining packages. Emphasis will be placed on employing these techniques to marketing, risk management, business negotiation and commercial applications.

title: Service Systems
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
description: Overview of the evolution of information systems and technologies used in selected service industries, such as health care, finance, insurance, hospitality, telecommunication, retail, etc. Examination of the unique features of a service system as a product or service. Qualitative and Quantitative methods for analyzing, designing, and operating service systems. User influence. Systems Development.
outcome: 1       1.      Understand the use of systems in selected service industries. 2.      Identify system features for service operations. 3.      Be able to apply qualitative and quantitative methods for service systems. 4.      Appreciate the importance of user influence. 5.      Understand managerial and technical issues in developing service systems.

title: Technology, Consulting and Analytics in Practice
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3512, ESTR4504 or SEEM3680.
description: This course aims to equip students with an overview of the latest technologies, e.g. cloud computing, social media, mobile applications, etc. that are impacting the business world every day. It also enable students to learn how some of the latest technology solutions are applied to the business world to solve real-life problems.Students will be given ample opportunity to apply what they have learned in class through participations in facilitated class discussions and sharing, and possibly with pilot technological implementations. The SEEM department will invite participation by industry leaders and practitioners to share their insights in this course.

title: Computational Finance
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4506. Prerequisite: SEEM2520 or SEEM3570 or SEEM3590 or ESTR3508 or ESTR3509.
description: In depth examination of numerical methods and their implementation for finance and risk management problems: Linear and Nonlinear Equation solutions, Unconstrained and constrained optimization, Monte Carlo Simulation, Finite difference for PDEs. Other related financial applications.
outcome: 1       1.      Examine the use of numerical methods for financial and risk management problems. 2.      Develop the ability to implement these applications.

recommended_readings: P. Brandimarte. Numerical methods in finance and economics: a matlab-based introduction. 2nd Edition. Johns Wiley & Sons.

title: Statistics Modeling and Analysis in Financial Engineering
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4508.
description: Financial data are undoubtedly rich from stock markets and many websites and sources such as Bloomberg and Reuters. This course studies empirical research methods in financial engineering, i.e., deriving intelligence from data through data analysis and statistical inference. In particular, this course addresses important issues of a statistical nature such as: use of different financial market data models, estimation of model parameters, simplification of models, and elaboration of models. The key objective of this course is to address how the prices of stocks and other financial assets behave.
outcome: At the completion of the course, the students should have the ability to: 1. master the basic knowledge of probability and statistical modeling in financial engineering;  2. appreciate the inherent features of financial markets and understand how to use time series models (including GARCH model) to model and to predict the market movement; 3. use statistical analysis to analyze the market data, to support investment decision and to determine option price; 4. use software tools to implement statistical applications for financial analysis.
syllabus: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.
required_readings: David Ruppert, Statistics and Finance: An Introduction, Springer, New York, 2004.
recommended_readings: According to the course teacher in the respective teaching term.

title: Advances in Logistics and Supply Chain Management
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4500 or ESTR4502 or ESTR4510 or SEEM4600 or SEEM4610.
description: This course covers the advanced topics in logistics and supply chain management. In particular, it uses comprehensive models to describe, and hence explore the optimal strategies in, various important logistics and supply chain management problems. The topics include customer service, channels of distribution, transportation, vehicle routing and scheduling, freight consolidation, facility location and network planning, storage. This course also introduces important practice in logistics and supply chain management, such as material handling systems, information systems for order processing and inventory tracking, purchasing and supply scheduling, business process re-engineering, third-party logistics, and global logistics.

title: Stochastic Models for Decision Analytics
academic_group: Dept of Sys Engg & Engg Mgt
requirements:

2. Not for students who have taken ESTR4512.
description: This course introduces the concepts of stochastic models and their applications in decision analytics. It covers the topics of Markov chains, Markov decision processes, and various approximate dynamic programing techniques.

Distributed system environment. Object-oriented approach. Engineering application: requirements and proposed solutions. Current topics. (Not for students who have taken CSE5120.)

title: Advanced Data Science for Systems Engineering
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in SEEM MPhil/PhD programme and RPg programmes under Faculty of Engineering
description: This graduate level course introduces the basic concepts of statistical pattern processing and machine learning algorithm. A particular focus is given on state-of-the-art machine learning techniques used in a set of application systems including but not limited to financial market models, pricing models, fraud detection, natural language processing, speech and audio technologies that are purposefully designed for the current SEEM research postgraduate students specializing in either of the two broad areas of information systems and operational research. This course is also available to undergraduate students of senior years with sufficient backgrounds in linear algebra, vector calculus, probability and statistics.

title: Seminars in Systems Engineering and Engineering Management (I)
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Students are required to attend all seminars during the term
outcome: Researchers and practitioners are invited to give seminars to share their experience with students on:  - The contemporary issues relevant to the discipline of operations research and information technology and their applications in engineering and managerial decision making, especially in financial services, logistics and supply chain management, business information systems, and service engineering and management; - The approaches to identify, formulate, and solve engineering problems; - The methods to design and conduct experiments, as well as to analyze and interpret data within realistic constraints, such as economic, environmental, social, political, ethical, health and safety, manufacturability and sustainability; - The ways to use the techniques, skills, and modern engineering tools necessary for engineering practice along with an understanding of their processes and limitations; - The impact of engineering solutions in a global and societal context, especially the importance of health, safety and environmental considerations; - Presenting and delivering the research outputs effectively.  By completion of the course, students should have acquired more knowledge in developing and carrying out their own research.

title: Speech and Language Processing
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in Mphil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Human-computer interaction using speech and language processing draws from the perspectives of speech science, linguistics, modeling techniques and algorithms from engineering, as well as system implementations. This course presents fundamentals in speech production and perception, phonetics and phonology and signal processing techniques for speech analysis. We will then proceed to discuss the probabilistic approaches and statistical methods for speech and language processing, with particular emphasis on automatic speech recognition and text-to-speech synthesis technologies, as well as integrated spoken language systems. The course will also cover aspects of pattern recognition that are impactful to the practice and implementation of information processing systems.
outcome: At the completion of the course, the student should have acquired the ability to understand  • the basic mechanisms of speech production and perception;  • the acoustic-phonetic descriptions of the speech signal;  • the speech analysis and related signal processing techniques;  • the state-of-the-art speech and language technologies;  • the integration of such technologies in spoken language systems.
recommended_readings: Huang, Acero & Hon, Spoken Language Processing: A Guide to Theory, Algorithms and System Development, Prentice Hall, 2001. Jelink, Statistical Methods for Speech Recognition, MIT Press 1997 Jurafsky & Martin, Speech & Language Processing, Pearson Education, 2000. Ladefoged,  A Course in Phonetics, Harcourt Brace Jovanovitch, 1982. Lee et al., Advances in Chinese Spoken Language Processing, 2006. Rabiner & Juang, Fundamentals of Speech Recognition, Prentice Hall 1993. Schultz & Kirchhoff, Multilingual Speech Processing, 2006. Waibel & Lee, Readings in Speech Recognition, 1990. Young et al. Cambridge University HTK Book

title: Stochastic Calculus
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Introduction to continuous time stochastic processes. Brownian motions: explicit constructions, properties, quadratic variation, the Cameron-Martin-Girsanov formula, multidimensional Brownian motions. Stochastic Integration: definition, Ito’s formula, martingale representation, time change, Girsanov’s Theorem, local time and Tanaka’s formula. Stochastic differential equations and diffusion processes: strong and weak solutions, diffusions, the Feynman-Kac formula, backward stochastic differential equations. Levy processes: definition, the Levy-Khinchin representation, the Levy-Ito decomposition, the Esscher transform.

title: Numerical Optimization
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in SEEM MPhil/PhD programme and RPg programmes under Faculty of Engineering
description: This course is to teach students modern numerical optimization methods for large scale systems. Topics covered in this course include gradient method, subgradient method, proximal gradient method, Nesterov's acceleration technique, alternating direction method of multipliers, coordinate descent method, and stochastic / randomized algorithms. Applications of these optimization methods for solving problems in contemporary applications arising from big data analytics, machine learning, statistics, signal processing etc. will also be discussed.
outcome: At the completion of this course, the student should  • familiarize with optimization algorithms for solving large scale optimization problems • understand the convergence behaviors of different algorithms • understand the capability of different algorithms • be able to use learned algorithms to solve practical problems
recommended_readings: • S. Boyd and L. Vandenberghe, Convex Optimization, Cambridge University Press, 2004 • D. Bertsekas, Nonlinear Programming, Athena Scientific, 1999 • J. Nocedal and S.J. Wright, Numerical Optimization, Springer, 2006 • Y. Nesterov, Introductory Lectures on Convex Optimization: A Basic Course, Kluwer, 2003

title: Term Structure Modeling of Interest Rates
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in SEEM MPhil/PhD programme and RPg programmes under Faculty of Engineering
description: The course is a systematic introduction to the development, analysis and implementation of interest rate models for pricing and hedging of fixed income derivatives. The materials will span the following aspects: linear interest rate product and yield curve construction; vanilla interest rate options and single rate models; interest rate exotics and the modeling of rates term structure. If time permits, we will also discuss typical trading strategies in the fixed income space, as well as hedging and management of interest rate exposures for fixed income portfolios, cashor derivative.

title: Topics in Behavioral Finance and Economics
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in SEEM MPhil/PhD programme and RPg programmes under Faculty of Engineering
description: Behavioral finance/economics is a relatively new field, which assumes economic agents to be irrational, in contrast to the rational assumption in neoclassical finance/economics. In this course, I introduce the history of behavioral finance and economics, and the recent development and potential research topics in this field. I will first introduce the foundation of neoclassical finance, portfolio selection and asset pricing models in neoclassical finance, and empirical evidence that is inconsistent with models in neoclassical finance. Then, I will introduce the basic principles of behavioral finance/economics, portfolio selection and asset pricing problems in neoclassical finance and new approaches to these problems, and empirical studies that are consistent with models in behavioral finance/economics. In addition to the recent development in behavioral finance/economics, I will also propose a variety of open research problems in this field.

title: Optimization Methods for High-Dimensional Statistics
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in SEEM MPhil/PhD programme and RPg programmes under Faculty of Engineering; Prerequisite: ENGG5501 or as approved by the course teacher
description: The prevalence of high-dimensional data has motivated active research on efficient methods for tackling optimization problems that arise in statistical analysis. In this course, we will give an introduction to this exciting area of research, with emphasis on the theory of structured regularizers for high-dimensional statistics and the design and analysis of statistically and computationally efficient optimization algorithms. Applications in various areas of science and engineering, such as machine learning, signal processing, and statistics, will also be discussed. Students are expected to have taken ENGG 5501 or equivalent.

title: Optimal Control
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Dynamic continuous-time systems. Examples, modelling, and classification of optimal control problems. Pontryagin’s maximum principle: adjoint equation, Hamiltonian system, and sufficient condition of optimality. Bellman’s dynamic programming: principle of optimality, Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation, and verification theorem. Linear quadratic control: Riccati equation and linear matrix inequality. Introduction to numerical methods of solving optimal control problems.
outcome: 1. Master the basic knowledge of mathematical modeling of dynamic systems, the concept of feedback, and theoretical framework of optimal control; 2. Understand how to derive optimal control policies under various conditions and how to implement them numerically. 3. Become familiar with research frontier in optimal control and its applications in management science and financial engineering.
required_readings: As recommended by course teacher.
recommended_readings: As recommended by course teacher.

title: Knowledge Systems
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: The roles of knowledge systems in problem solving. Automation of commonsense reasoning and extracting knowledge from data. Nonmonotonic and Plausible reasoning. Representation, statistical reasoning, and machine learning about quantities, measurements, time, and space. Knowledge systems to represent factors, topics, and goals.

title: Optimization I
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: The course covers the underlying theory and fundamental solution methodologies of mathematical programming: linear programming, unconstrained and constrained nonlinear optimization. Topics include optimality conditions, search methods, descent methods, Lagrange multipliers, penalty functions. Developments of duality theory are presented. Concepts and issues in global optimization and multi-objective optimization are introduced. Applications are drawn from engineering and financial optimization.

title: Numerical Methods in Finance
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: This course emphasizes the use of numerical methods for solving financial problems. The numerical methods include: binomial trees, Monte Carlo simulation, stochastic programming, linear/quadratic control models and semidefi nite programming techniques. Those techniques will be applied, among other things, to: option pricing, index tracking, portfolio optimization, interest rate models, and asset/liability management.

title: Advanced Stochastic Models
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Poisson process. Birth-and-death process, Markov chain. Martingale. Brownian motion. Renewal and stationary processes. Stochastic integration and Ito’s formula. Applications to queueing models, inventory models, and financial investment/hedging models.
outcome: • Understand stochastic models and their applications. • Be able to formulate and solve problems which involve setting up stochastic models.
recommended_readings: Sheldon Ross, Stochastic Processes, 2nd Edition, Wiley, New York, 1996

title: Stochastic Inventory and Revenue Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: This course is to equip students with the skills that enable them to formulate and analyse stochastic inventory and revenue management models. The fundamental concepts, methods, and results are presented, with an emphasis on the foundation of dynamic optimisation. The topics in inventory management include the classical (r,Q)/(s,S) models, and multi-echelon systems, and those in revenue management include dynamic pricing and booking controls and choice models.

title: Integer Programming
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: The course discusses underlying theory and fundamental solution methodologies for linear and nonlinear integer programming. Theoretical topics include general solution concepts such as relaxation, partition and bounds, submodularity, and duality theory. Solution methods covers partial enumeration methods, dynamic programming methods, branch and bound methods, cutting plane methods, convergent Lagrangian dual methods, convexification methods and global descent methods. These methods can be respectively applied to solve separable/non-separable and convex/non-convex integer programming problems, including nonlinear knapsack problems, quadratic integer programing, and zero-one polynomial integer programming. The course also discusses various applications of integer programming in engineering, management and finance.
outcome: 1. Understand how integer programming models are used for formulating and solving real-world decision making problems. 2. Know the basic concepts of complexity theory and understand the difference between ``easy'' problems and ``hard'' problems. 3. Understand the basic theory and methods for linear integer programming. 4. Understand duality theory for general integer programming. 5. Learn algorithmic techniques for different classes of nonlinear integer programming problems. 6. Be able to read, digest, and understand academic journal articles on integer programming

title: Advanced Models in Financial Engineering
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: This course covers various applications of engineering technicalities in financial modeling. Emphasis will be on two main topics: investment portfolio optimization and financial derivative pricing. We introduce dynamic programming approach, martingale and PDE numerical solutions, Monte Carlo simulation methods for solving these two problems.
outcome: 1. Understanding the essences of stochastic calculus, 2. Understanding the no-arbitrage principle and fundamental theory of asset pricing, 3. Be able to use the tool of Ito calculus to build up financial pricing models, 4. Be able to carry out PDE and probabilistic approaches to evaluate financial securities.
required_readings: S. E. Shreve, Stochastic Calculus for Finance II: Continuous-Time Models. Springer.
recommended_readings: 1. D. Duffie, Dynamic Asset Pricing, 3rd Edition, Princeton University Press. 2. P. Glasserman, Monte Carlo Methods in Financial Engineering, Springer. 3. YK, Kwok, Mathematical Models of Financial Derivatives, 2nd Edition, Springer.  4. M. Jeanblanc, M. Yor, and M. Chesney, Mathematical Methods for Financial Markets, Springer.

title: Text Mining Models and Application
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: This course covers basic mining models that are able to discover useful patterns and knowledge from text data. The form of text data ranges from semi-structured representation to free natural language texts. It discusses retrieval models as well as learning models based on user feedback. It also covers advanced models including language modeling, automatic entity extraction, and machine learning models suitable for text. Text mining applications such as knowledge management are presented.
outcome: At the completion of the course, the student should have acquired the ability to understand (i) techniques for text mining models (ii) text data analytics (iii) text mining applications
required_readings: “Mining Text Data”, Aggarwal C.C. and Zhai, C.X., Springer Science.
recommended_readings: (1) “Text Mining – Classification, Clustering, and Applications”, Srivastava A. and Sahami, M., CRC Press. (2) “Introduction to Information Retrieval”, Manning, C., Raghavan, P., Schutze, H., Cambridge University Press.

title: Principles of Operations Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: This course is designed to provide fundamental principles of managing engineering and industrial organizations. The focus is on the application of quantitative and qualitative approaches in the practice of engineering management. Quantitative modelling and solution techniques for strategic and operational problems are discussed. The role of strategic management, strategy formulation and strategy implementation are covered. Other strategic issues involving innovation and ethics are also addressed.
outcome: 1.     competence in building and manipulating quantitative models and solution techniques for decision-making, using spreadsheets and software, and2.     understanding of the issues involved in the interpretation, implementation and management of quantitative models, at both the strategic and operational level.
syllabus: Provided by course teacher.
required_readings: 1.Balakrishnan, Render, and Stair, Managerial Decision Modeling with Spreadsheets   (3rd Edition), 2014, Pearson (BRS)
recommended_readings: As recommended by course teacher.

title: Information Technology Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: The challenges, techniques and technologies associated with the management of information technology (IT) in a competitive environment. The linkage of IT to business strategy and business process re-engineering. Different types of information systems: MIS, DSS, TPS. Information technology concepts: networking, database, batch and distributed processing. Development Process. Information system planning. Systems project management and control. IT acquisition, budgeting and deployment. Performance evaluation and audit. Operations management, privacy and security.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students acquired skills for (1) long-term IT planning - the strategic perspectives of information system management, (2) mid-term IT planning – project selection and justification, and (3) short-term IT planning – project management; as well as emphasis on latest E-Commerce technologies
required_readings: Efraim Turban, Linda Volonio, “Information Technology for Management: Transforming Organizations in the Digital Economy”, 7th Edition, Wiley.

title: Engineering Economics
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Principles of engineering economy. Value and cost, cash flows. Economic analysis of alternatives, technological, social and human factors. Models involving allocation and scheduling of resources. Analytical techniques for evaluating industrial projects. Relationship between economics of technical choice and industrial productivity. Basic financial accounting concepts, financial statements.
outcome: At the conclusion of this course, students were able to  understand basic cost concepts, terminology, and methods to estimate and optimize cost of design projects; understand time value of money and apply this knowledge through various methods to evaluate alternative projects; and  learn the techniques to account for depreciation, tax, and inflation in the evaluation of engineering projects.
required_readings: Engineering Economy, William G. Sullivan; Elin M. Wicks; C. Patrick Koelling, Pearson Education, Limited
recommended_readings: As recommended by course teacher.

title: Expert Systems and Decision Support
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Overview of management support systems. Data and model management in decision support systems. Group decision process. Group decision support systems and distributed group decision support systems. Executive information and support systems. Applications of artificial intelligence methodologies in decision support. Integration of decision support technologies. Design and development of management support systems. Organizational and societal impacts.
outcome: Students are expected to learn the basic topics of knowledge representation, logic reasoning under uncertainly, the techniques of building expert systems and also the system language called CLIPS.
required_readings: As recommended by course teacher.
recommended_readings: As recommended by course teacher.

title: Client/Server Information Systems
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Introduction to distributed computing. Client/Server theory and practice. Overview of major protocols and distributed system concepts. Management aspects: vision, priority and transition strategies, operational challenges.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to acquire skills for 1. Assessing, acquiring, and managing latest computing resources available on the Internet for meeting different kinds of computing needs 2. Designing and developing newer web and mobile applications for business, personal, and social activities by leveraging on existing web resources 3. Allocating and planning investment vs. expenditure on computing resources to meet business objectives 4. Analyzing and understanding different underlying client-server computing models behind the latest set of applications that we use daily

title: Open Systems and Electronic Commerce
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Introduction to open system standards and protocols. Transaction protocols. Electronic commerce applications using open system and artificial intelligence technologies. Application of intelligent agents for automated transaction processing. Integration of HTML and JAVA with information and communication systems.
outcome: At the completion of the course, students are expected to gain knowledge on the algorithms, mechanisms, and protocols used in the current Internet, and gain knowledge on how to develop network applications to support e-commerce applications, and how to support different needs required in e-commerce applications that deal with a large amount of data.
required_readings: 1. Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach Featuring the Internet (5th edition) by James F. Kurose and Keith W. Ross, Addison Wesley, 2009. 2. Introduction to Data Mining, by Pang-Ning Tan, Michael Steinbach, and Vipin Kumar, Addison Wesley, 2005. 3. Community Detection and Mining in Social Media, by Lei Tang and Huan Liu, Morgan & Claypool Publisher, 2010.
recommended_readings: As recommended by course teacher.

title: Project and Technology Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: The main objective of this course is to teach students the basic concepts, models, and techniques in key functional areas of project management, including project screening and selection, project organization, scheduling, budgeting, allocation of depletable and renewable resources, project control, and computer support. Technology management and its relationships with project management will also be introduced.
outcome: Students are expected to gain deep understanding and mastery of the relevant knowledge to effectively manage industrial and technological projects.
required_readings: A, Shtub, J.F. Bard, and S. Globerson, Project Management: Engineering, Technology, and Implementation, Prentice Hall, 1994.
recommended_readings: D.L. Babcock, Managing Engineering and Technology, 3rd Edition, Prentice Hall, 2002

title: Logistics Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Logistics planning. The integrated logistics management concept. Customer service. Channel of distribution system. Order processing and information system. Transportation system. Storage and material handling system. Warehousing. Purchasing. Inventory management. Global logistics. Managing the supply chain.
outcome: At the end of the course, the student is expected to have: 1. acquired knowledge and skills in modeling, analyzing and optimizing key logistics processes (e.g. location and network design, routing and scheduling, etc.) 2. understood the tradeoffs and interplay among the many objectives and processes in logistics management, and  gained an appreciation of the complexities of logistics operations in practice.
required_readings: Ghiani, G., G. Laporte and R. Musmanno, Introduction to Logistics Systems Management, 2013, Wiley.
recommended_readings: 1. Ballou, R.H., Business Logistics Management/Supply Chain Management, 5th edition, 2004, Prentice-Hall. 2. Christopher, M., Logistics and Supply Chain Management (4th edition), 2011, Financial Times/ Prentice-Hall. 3. Chopra, S. and P. Meindl, Supply Chain Management (4th edition), 2010, Prentice-Hall.  4. Powell and Baker, Management Science: the art of modeling with spreadsheets (2nd Edition), 2009, Wiley.

title: Introduction to Financial Engineering
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Models of risks. Utility functions, and mean-variance theory. Probability models and price dynamics of securities. Geometric Brownian motion, Ito’s lemma, Black-Scholes model. Capital asset pricing. Risk hedging. Optimization techniques. Applications to investment and portfolio management. The emphasis is on mathematical modelling, analysis and computation.
outcome: After completing the course, students are expected to have basic knowledge of the financial market, investment, risk management, and financial derivatives.
syllabus: Provided by course teacher.
required_readings: D. G. Luenberger, Investment Science, 2nd edition, Oxford University Press, 2013
recommended_readings: As recommended by course teacher.

title: Stochastic Investment Models
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: The focus of the course is on various stochastic models that support investment decisions. Overview of investment problems: cash flow analysis, introduction of asset classes, mean-variance theory, expected utility theory, data-driven portfolio optimization, capital asset pricing model, arbitrage pricing theory, dynamic programming, market micro-structure.
outcome: To acquaint students with the modeling and analysis of financial investment problems under uncertainly, and methodologies for solving them.
syllabus: Provided by course teacher.
required_readings: As recommended by course teacher.
recommended_readings: As recommended by course teacher.

title: Quantitative Risk Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: Introduction of financial risk, standard deviation, tail risk, extreme value theory, correlation and copula, risk attribution and capital allocation, credit risk, liquidity risk, operational risk.
outcome: After completing the course, students are expected to know various models of financial risk and quantitative methods of risk management.
syllabus: Provided by course teacher.
required_readings: M. B. Miller, Quantitative Financial Risk Management, Wiley, 2019
recommended_readings: A. J. McNeil, R. Frey, and P. Embrechts, Quantitative Risk Management: Concepts, Techniques and Tools, revised edition, Princeton University Press, 2015

locations: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT

title: Computational Finance
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: The course emphasizes the implementation of numerical algorithms applied to financial problems. The numerical methods include: binomial trees, Monte Carlo simulation, finite difference methods, among others. These methods will be applied to basic options, exotic options, futures, term structure, fixed income securities, dynamic trading strategies and financial risk management.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should (1) acquire basic knowledge about the fixed-income security market, equity market, and derivative markets and (2) master basic numerical methods in financial applications.
syllabus: Provided by course teacher.
required_readings: John C. Hull, Options, Futures and Other Derivatives, 7th Edition, Prentice Hall, Upper Saddle River, NJ, 2009.
recommended_readings: Zvi Bodie, Alex Kane, Alan J. Marcus, Essentials of Investments, 8th Edition, McGraw Hill, 2010.

locations: William M W Mong Eng Bldg LT

title: Supply Chain Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: This course introduces the key models and concepts in supply chain management. Topics include: demand forecasting, aggregate planning, supply management, inventory management, matching supply with uncertain demand, information distortion and demand management, information technologies for supply chain co-ordination, e-business models, etc.
outcome: This course considers the operation of a supply chain from a managerial perspective. The course has three major objectives:  1. To give students a solid understanding of the major issues in SCM.  2. To provide tools for design, analysis, management and performance improvement of supply chains.  3. To introduce and discuss concepts widely adopted in supply chain management.  This course emphasizes analytical skills. Being analytical does not mean mathematical, but basic calculus and the Normal Distribution will be used to facilitate the understanding of why/how some powerful concepts/innovations work.
required_readings: Chopra and Meindl, Supply Chain Management: Strategy, Planning and Operation, 5th edition, 2013, Pearson
recommended_readings: 1. Heizer and Render, Operations Management: Sustainability and Supply Chain Management, 11th edition, 2014, Pearson 2. Nahmias, Production and Operations Analysis, 6th Edition, 2008, Irwin/McGraw-Hill

title: Project in Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc Systems Engineering and Engineering Management
description: This course is designed to put theory into practice on issues from various fields including Logistics Management, Information Technology , and Financial Engineering and so on. With company visits and field studies being required, stuents are encouraged to go out of the textbooks, and go out of the campus on the same time. Accordingly, the course includes two parts: company visits and project work with optional topics. For the company visit activities, students are organized to visit different kinds of companies and enterprises, such as bank, logistics company, insurance carrier, airline, retailer company, and government organizations, to help them understand different business operating environments and their approaches for solution development. For the project work part, under the supervision of the course instructor, students in groups will carry out a practical project in Systems Engineering & Engineering Management, by building models on practical problems, performing quantitative analysis and making decisions.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have acquired skills for (1) recognizing different company characters and cultures in various industries, (2) cooperating with group members and developing team spirits, (3) using quantitative models to analyze and solve practical problems, and (4) making impressive slides and presenting project outcomes formally.
required_readings: 1. Robert T. Clemen, Making Hard Decisions: An Introduction to Decision Analysis, Duxbury Press, 1996. 2. A, Shtub, J.F. Bard, and S. Globerson, Project Management: Engineering, Technology, and Implementation, Prentice Hall, 1994. 3. Chopra and Meindl, Supply Chain Management: Strategy, Planning and Operation, Pearson, 2013. 4. Jiawei Han and Micheline Kamber, Data Mining: Concepts and Techniques, Morgan Kaufmann, 2001. Efraim Turban, Jae K Lee, David King, Ting Peng Liang, Deborrah Turban: Electronic Commerce 2010 – A Managerial Perspective, Prentice Hall, 2010.
recommended_readings: As recommended by course teacher.
